title: The Bandwidth Bottleneck Holding Blockchains Back | Mateo Ward & Austin Federa

the magic?" It's no magic. It's just
what did every other tech platform do
when they needed to become high
performance and scale? They built a

network underneath. What's up, guys?

Welcome back to another episode of Xerox

on guys. Thanks. Great to be here.
Thanks for having us. Perfect. Before we

I kind of want to get a bit of
background on both of you and what you
guys do over at zero, if that works.
Yeah, sure. All right. Uh so I am one of

am the co-founder that is attached to
the foundation side of the project. So
um I also serve as the president of the

zero and co-founding this thing. Uh I

And I'm Matteo Ward. I'm the co-founder

fantastic. And another uh introductory
question, what is exactly zero and how
is it beneficial to the general crypto
landscape?
Go for it.
Well, um I guess people on the internet
are tired of hearing Austin say it, so
we'll try to give it a little different
spin this time. Um zeros is a alternate
internet, a purpose-built internet for
distributed systems. And what that means
is that it's not a general purpose
network. And you might find it funny to
hear someone describing a project in the
negative, but it's very very important
to understand the difference between
general purpose and purpose-built. And
so basically what we do is we say what
does a time-sensitive distributed global
system need in order to operate at high
performance and we build a purposeful
network that is exactly focused on
delivering that performance. Uh so
that's what double0ero is high level.
We'll dive into more of the details of
how it works, but um you know, basically
it's really fast, a really fast highway
for cars to drive on. Perfect. Um and
why why do we why do we need it? Um in
the sense that I read over some of
the tweets that Austin put out as well
as your white paper and one thing you
guys mentioned is that compute is not
the uh bottleneck anymore and that um
the bottleneck
is bandwidth limitations. that's the
word. Um what what does that mean? Um
more simply and then maybe you can dive
into why zero is necessary.
I think I'll start with the high level
and then I always love to hear Austin
talking about why the bottleneck exists
in blockchain specifically. But if you
look at the high level, every single
tech segment and industry has gone
through an evolution where they start
out at a hobbyist level work running on
whatever internet they can get their
hands on. Uh whether it be a land party
uh for gamers or whether it be the
public internet for networks like
YouTube when they started out or Netflix
when they started out. And I don't know
if you remember if you ever watched
Netflix or YouTube pre-private network,
but around 2006, Google um deployed
their global private network and YouTube
started using that and all of a sudden
you stopped getting buffering and delays
and bad user experiences. The same thing
has happened in cloud networking. um
AWS, uh Google Cloud, all the big
providers have these huge private
networks, purpose-built networks, um
based on submarine fiber, terrestrial
fiber, all linked together. Uh and so,
you know, basically the time has come
where blockchain needs to do the same as
every other tech industry. So, um a lot
of people are like, "Oh, what's the
magic?" It's no magic. It's just what
did every other tech platform do when
they needed to become high performance
and scale? they built a purpose-built um
custom dedicated network underneath and
we got to blockchain and we said, "Oh,
blockchain has some specific issues and
that's where Austin can kind of help us
get that insight."
Perfect.
Um Austin, do you have anything you want
to add? Yeah, so I mean this is kind of
one of those funny things where when
people talk about the problems in
blockchain today, they're really focused
a lot on compute. And one of the
questions you should always ask yourself
is why, right? Why is compute the thing
that gets so much attention and because
it's kind of the easiest thing to solve,
right? You you people solve the problem
that they know how to solve and the
problem that is immediately in front of
their face. And so a good question to
ask yourself is why are test net numbers
always so much higher than mainet
numbers? Right? And there there's two
there's two reasons for this. One is
mainet load is different than test net
load. That's that's very kind of
important to remember. The other though
is that test nets are usually small
deployments in se like small data
centers or they're running in much more
controlled environments. And the thing
that we've seen from like pretty much I
would say mid 2021 onwards are that
validator clients now the software that
actually runs these things can do very
high performance systems. Now if you go
back to 2018 and you ran GE locally you
weren't getting over you know 200 to 400
transactions per second on the EVM.
That's different nowadays. You look at
something like Salana and you can do a
million transactions per second on the
Fire Dancer client. You can do close to
that um on the Agave client as well. And
you can actually look at like uh you
know how does that actually scale out
when you're looking at a test net. And
one of the pieces you run into is if you
were at breakpoint last year, you saw a
demo of a million transactions per
second running on uh you know I think it
was six nodes on four continents and
that was actually running on the zero
network. If you'd run that demo in the
public internet you would not have
gotten a million transactions per
second. And so really we've we've
reached this point where for years it
was the software that was holding
blockchains back. And it's no longer the
software. And so like our our goal at
double zero is to like make it the fault
of the software people again.
Very good. Um one one thing I want to
ask about is we typically
um say that consensus is an issue coming
to consensus is an issue because um
let's say New York and Japan need to
communicate like validators in New York
and validators in Japan. Is this what um
zero would help out with? that would be
much much quicker because it wouldn't
get routed through some random.
Yeah, there there's there's like a bunch
of different ways to think about this
and I think probably the easiest to
start out with and I'll have Matteo do
the harder one is like the pointto-point
communications, right? And so if I am
trying to talk to a computer in
Singapore from New York, traffic will
bounce all around the United States uh
you know before it actually heads in the
right direction and eventually gets over
to Singapore. There's a bunch of reasons
for this. The main is business use cases
um which is that like the the way that
these business models are constructed
over the last 30 years is not to
incentivize performance. It's to
incentivize basically least cost routing
and getting data off your network as
quickly as possible. And so even just on
the onetoone example of I'm just trying
to send a packet from New York to
Singapore, it's not going to take an
efficient route because the business the
business models basically don't support
that today. Like you'd be surprised to
learn this, but there's actually no way
to pay for packet prioritization on the
public internet today. Like I can't just
say, "Oh, I'm willing to spend a bit
more money like a jetto tip or something
like that and get this thing processed
more quickly." Like there just that
doesn't exist. Um and then there's a
whole other problem which you know
Matteo can talk about of the one to many
communication style of blockchain which
the internet just wasn't built for.
Yeah. Yeah, I mean just to add on to
that, why does the traffic bounce around
all over the US, all over the world? Uh
it's related to the way internet routes
traffic. Uh you can see on my shirt
here, this is the uh the current ASN
number, autonomous system number that
we're using on test net. And it's one
ASN for the whole world. Uh that sounds
simple, but that's a huge statement
because on the internet you've got
dozens and hundreds of different ASN
numbers. Each one is a different network
and they have to pass traffic between
them and they use a protocol called
border gateway protocol BGP to do that
and as Austin said the BGP attributes
that route that traffic have many
different factors it could even be
geopolitical be like don't cross over
this country could be use this border
router only in Dallas when the traffic
needs to go to Seattle it's going to
route through Dallas think about it as
an airline um hub system right you know
if if you're going to have to take a
connection uh on a coast to coast
flight, it's never going to be the
direct straight line. And so you're
always going to go through a hub. It's
the exact same thing here. And what the
magic of what zero does is it routes the
entire world on a single ASN number,
which means that every single packet
goes straight to uh the location that
it's going to. And there's peering
between every node on the zero network
and every other node on the zero
network. And that is not the case in the
internet. There's peering at the edge.
There's peering at these specific
points. Carriers fight with each other
and then they depear and then you can't
ever deliver traffic directly to that
city. There's so many different things
that happen. And we've solved that by
having this single mesh of peered
routers all around the world under a
single ASN number. And we've done it in
a decentralized fashion with multiple
network providers, which is the key
because any other network that's like
this one is a centralized, privately
owned network. And we've brought that
into the public domain. We've made it
decentralized and we've made a whole
community of contributors that make up
that unified network. Yeah. And this
really is like where you need tokens,
right? Like a lot like we get asked
every once in a while like, oh, like do
you really need tokens? Couldn't you
just build this as like an equity
company? The answer is like no because
we need the ability for everyone in the
link of the chain, for lack of a better
term, every single network provider that
you pass through to get from New York to
Singapore in the most efficient route
possible to get paid. And that that's
like sounds like such a basic insight,
but like that is not how the internet
works today for the most part. Um, and
so being able to have these things where
as Matteo was talking about the
incentive of every provider is to
provide as most useful service as
possible because they'll earn the most
rewards, right? The links that are give
the biggest advantage over the public
internet are and reach the most amount
of stake or validators or RPCs are the
ones that are rewarded most on the zero
network. And so the incentive for
everyone is how can I make my links as
performant as possible and as useful as
possible which like again sounds like
the way the internet should work but
it's not actually the way the internet
works and this is really only possible
with tokens. That makes sense. I'm glad
you guys brought up both tokens and
contributors because I want to ask about
this. Um Mateo maybe first to you
because you brought up the contributor
side. What who are the different

involved parties that you guys have to
deal with and that you guys have to
coordinate with? Yeah, let's start up
high level. It's anybody that has
network that's high performance, low
latency, low jitter and wants to
contribute it to a global new version of
the internet. And when you look at that
high level, you're like, wow, this is a
huge market opportunity. Um when
Starlink was launching their project
they they took the TAM to be a trillion
dollars which is the annual amount of
revenue on the internet. A trillion
dollars they wanted to get 3 to 5% of
that 30 to 50 billion and today they're
at 11 billion. They're doing fine. Um
and so there is a massive global market
for connectivity and there's lots of
people that own capacity. And so a new
use case for applying that to um a
monetizable project is wonderful for all
of these uh people that own networks.
And so really the the addressable
contributor base is anyone who owns and
operates a high performance network that
wants to be part of a new internet. Um
zooming in and making that into a
timeline, you get different phases. you
get the early adopters and those early
adopters are the ones who probably
understand blockchain. They understand
what a utility token is and and the
value that might come out of that. Um
they have underutilized capacity. So
they've got a global network that's
being used for another use case in house
and they have a slice of that that they
could contribute. um and they're
risk-takers and and people that want to
believe in something new, sort of
bleeding edge uh tech adopters. And this
is a really fun group. These are the the
ones that have initially committed to to
the network. You've seen them in some of
our press releases. You've got uh
companies like Jump Crypto. You've got
um uh other VCs that have uh
contributed. We've got Rockaway X. We've

number of people that said, "I'm going
to make a bet on this because I think
it's the future." And then you've got
phase two, which are the wait and see

of those where they say, "Oh, wow. I see

value here. I can create a business
case. I can do uh an ROI analysis and
I'm going to go in that." And that
includes also carriers and other

frequency trading firms or others that
just have a network and want to
contribute it. Um retail companies and
others, they all have private customuilt
networks because they all need to move

you've got phase three which is equally
interesting which is entrepreneurs,
capitalists and all kinds of people.
They're like, "Wow, I've got this
ecosystem now that's a a tokenized
version of telecom tap capex and of
shared networks and I can pull together

someone who's going to provide me with
data center space. I can find someone
who's going to lease hardware. I can
find someone who's going to lease me
connectivity. I can pull it all together
and contribute it to the zero network
and earn tokens on that." And and that's
really the the the end vision that that
this really becomes viral because um
after the institutions if you get this
thriving ecosystem of entrepreneurs um
contributing assets to the network it
really scales quickly.
That makes sense. So the first I guess
users that will be onboarded apart from

mainly people who already have these

isn't something that I could do for

Yeah. I mean this is you can think about

the role of infrastructure in

um what typically I guess deepen um

sometimes it can go down in value as we

where you wanted to maybe go with USDC
instead am I doing something that's not
the problem with deepen the problem with

local currency The problem with deepin
is there's usually no demand side.
There's only supply side, right? And any
market where all you have is supply
side, you're going to get a
downward-looking graph, right? Um and
so, you know, one of the things that I
think is really important with with
double zero, there's kind of a few
different things we've done. For
example, there's no base level
contribution reward. Just for running a
piece of fiber, you by default get
nothing. If that piece of fiber is not
useful, if it's not providing
connectivity into areas where people run
uh you know Salana validators or RPCs or
any other type of infrastructure on the
network, you're not going to get

fiber. Most deepin networks, they give
you sort of this passive coverage or

farming. And it's um it is extremely
hard to farm zero tokens without
providing actual value to the network,
which at that point is not called
farming. is just called being a good
network contributor, right? And so a lot
of this is just like good economic and
system design. A lot of this credit goes
to Nihar who is our chief economist over
at the foundation and has done a ton of
work on this type of thing. Um but the
other piece too is like we are charging
validators to use 0ero. We're charging
RPCs to use and so the network once it
launches in mainet assuming people adopt
it will have revenue inflows to it. And
so, you know, the the way that this
works is it's not like we're just
minting a bunch of tokens every month to
give out to network contributors, right?
This isn't an this isn't a network that
operates that way. Um, validators and
RPCs pay to use the zero network. Uh,
those are rewards are, you know, if
they're paid in native soul or if
they're paid in zero, either way, they
end up in this reward pool. They're all
converted into zero tokens. a portion of
those are burned and then a portion of
those are distributed out to the network
contributors. So, it's not like we have,
you know, like a 10% inflation rate and
we're just like printing a bunch of new
tokens for network contributors. It is
revenue derived. Um, and we think this
is like a good solid framework to build
this stuff out. Um, we do have a
property right now where a number of our
uh contributors are also investors in
the project. And so, you know, there is
obviously with any deepen network, there
is a cold start problem. And that's sort
of the way we're we're working on a
bunch of that cold start problem. But,
you know, these are these are the type
of systems where like if we're not doing
our job and the network's not generating

means we haven't done this thing
correctly yet. And so I think the um you
see this very web two model in a lot of
like networks nowadays of grow the thing
and like uh you know we'll figure out
how to make it valuable in the future
and that works if it's useful right like
I think like the thesis for Salana and
like this was always to thing when I
would talk to him about this back in
like 2020 and 21 was like or end of end

need to make Salana useful and then
we'll figure out how to make it valuable
and The problem with most deepen
networks is they're not useful. They're

A lot of new L1s fall into this
category. As long
as useful and so that means we have
validators and RPCs choosing to connect

of it. Um, and we're able to provide,

reduced latency. the monetization side

economics.xyz about like how these

That makes sense. Um, one thing I want

Um, and they had very low low take rate.
I think they ran at a loss for the first

I assume the 5% is not the initial rate.
Is that correct? No, it's a it's a it's

let's just get let's just fast forward

same it to me it feels very spiritually

or tokens that launch before a network

You've found if you open up an ATM on

uh above and beyond what the public

believe worth paying for and if other

that doesn't mean it's not worth paying
for right that means that we haven't

utility is not quite there. Um but
fundamentally this cannot exist as a
free network
because physical infrastructure is
expensive. Th this is something that I I
feel really strongly about and I've been

And so I think we're really well
